sn22.150:1.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what, do pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn22.150:1.3: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn22.150:1.4: “When form exists, because of grasping form, pleasure and pain arise in oneself.
sn22.150:1.8: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness, pleasure and pain arise in oneself.
sn22.150:1.12: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.150:1.14: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn22.150:1.21: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.150:1.23: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn22.150:1.26: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
